abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Water Quality and
            Pollution Control Project to the States of Sao Paulo and
            Parana were as follows: outcome was satisfactory;
            sustainability was likely; institutional development impact
            was substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. The ratings for the
            Espirito Santo Water Coastal Pollution Management Project
            were as follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory;
            sustainability was likely; institutional development impact
            was negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons
            learned included: (i) the importance of treating the
            institutional and environmental objectives as long term
            program areas, rather than projects, and this requires
            persistence, patience, and follow up by the Bank; (ii) that
            integrated approaches work well, for the most part, with low
            income settlements; (iii) that the hybrid approach
            represents a useful model for Brazil and elsewhere; and (iv)
            that metropolitan planning in Brazil requires urgent
            attention. One of the richest lessons from this assessment,
            finally, concerns the perceptions and judgments of high
            level professionals who managed the course of project
            implementation. Institutional actors were given the scope to
            form and agree on core values.

repnme.cdata!:
Improving water supply and sanitation in
            Sao Paulo

abstracts.cdata!:
In urban areas of Brazil, such as Sao
            Paulo, growing slums are major contributors to the pollution
            of water sources. These slum dwellers, living on public land
            and irregular plots, tend to concentrate in precarious,
            flood-prone areas in the basin, and have no appropriate
            infrastructure for water supply, sewerage, drainage, and
            solid waste management. Their domestic waste therefore
            contributes directly to the pollution of the water
            reservoir. In the 1990s the World Bank decided to support
            the state of Sao Paulo with a project that sought to
            guarantee the Guarapiranga reservoir as a reliable water
            source, capable of supplying some 3 million people in the
            metropolitan area of Sao Paulo. The project provided 8,050
            new connections to the existing sewerage system and 41,000
            connections prepared for the new sewerage system.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Water Quality and Pollution
            Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project shows a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. The integrated approach
            to water quality management - water supply and sanitation
            services, urban upgrading and other basic needs at the local
            levels - is based on multi-sectoral, and inter-institutional
            principles, and is inherently complex. Despite successes,
            and notwithstanding the Bank's 1993 Water Resources
            Policy Paper acknowledging the need for comprehensive water
            resources, planning and management at the river basin level
            (though warning of its difficulties), and the 2003 Water
            Resources Sector Strategy endorsing pragmatic approaches to
            policy reform, in recognition of the political economy of
            changes, difficulties still persist in inter-municipal and
            state-municipal cooperation, and coordination to control
            pollution in highly urbanized river basins. In the final
            analysis, problems related to water quality management,
            pollution control, the environment, and urban upgrading,
            remain complex - both institutionally and in terms of the
            interactions between land uses, infrastructure, pollution,
            and the resulting water quality - which cannot be resolved
            with simple approaches, or isolated sector interventions.
            This experience  demonstrates that a fundamental element of
            such urban water management projects, is the concomitant
            concern with addressing urban poverty and quality of life.
            In response, quality assurance sought to demonstrate an
            approach for comprehensive planning, and management that
            could help overcome the difficulties of coordination, and
            how to achieve effective integration, while demonstrating
            the importance of using the river basin, and sub-basins,
            and, it confirmed that comprehensive urban water resources,
            land-use planning and management, is feasible although
            complex, time consuming, and subject to political risk.
